root.publications: Lynch, John. 1999. Southern Oceanic linguistic history, Le Pacifique de 5000 à 2000 avant le présent: Suppléments à l'histoire d'une colonisation/The Pacific from 5000 to 2000 BP: Colonisation and transformations, 423-449. Paris: Éditions de IRD (Institut de Recherche pour le Développment). , Lynch, John. 2000. Linguistic subgrouping in Vanuatu and New Caledonia. In Paul Geraghty & Bill Palmer (eds.), Sicol Proceedings of the Second International Conference on Oceanic Linguistics: Vol 2, Historical and Descriptive Studies, vol. 2, 155-184. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858834766
root.pub-comments: “That is, Proto Southern Oceanic was probably spoken somewhere in northern Vanuatu, and probably spread across a number of the northern islands fairly rapidly—Banks, Torres, Maewo, Ambae, Santo, and north Pentecost. At some stage, speakers of one or more of these dialects moved further south, where again dialect differentiation took place, developing eventually into various Central Vanuatu linkages” (Lynch 1999:439).

Southern Oceanic linguistic history, Le Pacifique de 5000 à 2000 avant le présent: Suppléments à l'histoire d'une colonisation/The Pacific from 5000 to 2000 BP: Colonisation and transformations, 423-449. Paris: Éditions de IRD (Institut de Recherche pour le Développment). , Lynch, John. 2000. Linguistic subgrouping in Vanuatu and New Caledonia. In Paul Geraghty & Bill Palmer (eds.), Sicol Proceedings of the Second International Conference on Oceanic Linguistics: Vol 2, Historical and Descriptive Studies, vol. 2, 155-184. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858834766
child.pub-comments: “Note also that Southern Melanesian is classed as a family: i.e., there appears to have been a single ancestral language, which underwent a split presumably as a result of migration from the Southern Vanuatu area into New Caledonia” (Lynch 1999:428).

child.publications: Lynch, John. 1999. Southern Oceanic linguistic history, Le Pacifique de 5000 à 2000 avant le présent: Suppléments à l'histoire d'une colonisation/The Pacific from 5000 to 2000 BP: Colonisation and transformations, 423-449. Paris: Éditions de IRD (Institut de Recherche pour le Développment). , Lynch, John. 2000. Linguistic subgrouping in Vanuatu and New Caledonia. In Paul Geraghty & Bill Palmer (eds.), Sicol Proceedings of the Second International Conference on Oceanic Linguistics: Vol 2, Historical and Descriptive Studies, vol. 2, 155-184. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858834766
child.pub-comments: Lynch (1999, 2000) mentions various languages that he labels as “New Caledonian” but he does not specify which of the three subgroups they belong to or include them in the tree. The languages are: Kumak [nee], Xârâcùù [ane], Cèmuhî [cam], Iaai [iai], Nengone [nen], Pwapwâ [pop], Nyelâyu [yly], PaicÎ [pri], and Yuanga [nua]. “The internal subgrouping of the New Caledonian subgroup, which may be a family or a linkage, is still being researched” (Lynch 1999:428).

child.pub-comments: Lynch lists one other language as “Southern Vanuatu”: Ura [uur]. However, in this article, he does not specify whether Ura is a member of Erromango, Tanna, or Aneityom.
